skill.name: ralph-tui-prd
skill.description: Generate a Product Requirements Document (PRD) for ralph-tui task orchestration. Creates PRDs with user stories that can be converted to beads issues or prd.json for automated execution. Triggers on: create a prd, write prd for, plan this feature, requirements for, spec out.

skill.author: subsy

security_audit.summary: All static findings are false positives. The file is pure markdown documentation (SKILL.md) for generating Product Requirements Documents. The detected backticks are markdown formatting for displaying example commands, not shell execution. No cryptographic operations or dangerous code patterns exist in this documentation file.

content.value_statement: This skill helps product teams create detailed Product Requirements Documents for AI agent execution. It guides users through clarifying questions about feature goals, scope, and quality gates, then generates structured PRDs with user stories and acceptance criteria.
actual_capabilities: Guides users through clarifying questions to capture feature requirements
Generates structured PRDs with user stories, goals, and acceptance criteria
Defines quality gates that must pass for each story
Creates unambiguous functional requirements and out-of-scope items
Formats output for ralph-tui task orchestration tool
limitations: Does not implement features - only creates planning documents
Does not access external systems or APIs
Does not execute code or run commands
Requires user input to answer clarifying questions

use_cases.title: New Feature Planning
use_cases.description: Product managers use this skill to transform feature ideas into detailed PRDs that AI agents can execute, ensuring nothing is missed during implementation.

use_cases.title: Complex Feature Scoping
use_cases.description: Development teams use the skill to break down complex features into small, independently completable user stories with clear acceptance criteria.

use_cases.title: Cross-Team Alignment
use_cases.description: Teams create shared documentation that serves as a single source of truth for stakeholders, developers, and AI agents executing the work.

prompt_templates.title: Basic PRD Request
prompt_templates.scenario: Starting a new feature that needs structured requirements documentation

prompt_templates.title: Refined Feature Request
prompt_templates.prompt: Create a PRD for adding [feature] to [product/context]. The main goal is to [business objective].
prompt_templates.scenario: When you have some context about the feature but need structured exploration

prompt_templates.title: Detailed PRD Request
prompt_templates.prompt: Create a PRD for [feature]. Target users are [user type]. Key requirements: [brief list]. Quality commands: [specific commands that must pass].
prompt_templates.scenario: When you have partial requirements and want to fill gaps through Q&A

prompt_templates.title: Quick PRD from Issue
prompt_templates.prompt: Create a PRD based on this issue description: [paste issue content]. Ask me clarifying questions if needed.
prompt_templates.scenario: Converting a GitHub issue or bug report into a full PRD

output_examples.input: Create a PRD for adding a search feature
output: I need some clarifying questions first to create a useful PRD.
A. Help users find content faster
B. npm run typecheck && npm run lint
C. bun run typecheck && bun run lint
Please answer with the letter(s) of your choices, or provide your own answers.

output_examples.input: Create a PRD for a notification system. Target: all users. Key: email and push notifications.
output: Add email and push notification capabilities so users stay informed about important updates.
- Keep users informed about relevant activity
- Provide preference controls for notification types
- Maintain performance with high notification volume
**Description:** As a user, I want to configure which notifications I receive so that I stay informed without being overwhelmed.
- [ ] Settings page includes notification preferences section
- [ ] Users can toggle email notifications on/off
- [ ] Users can toggle push notifications on/off

best_practices: Answer all clarifying questions thoroughly - each answer helps create a more accurate PRD
Specify quality gates early so stories include proper verification steps
Keep user stories small enough to complete in one focused session
anti_patterns: Providing minimal information and expecting a complete PRD without Q&A
Requesting implementation alongside PRD creation - this skill only plans
Skipping quality gates - they are critical for story verification

faq.question: What triggers this skill?
faq.answer: Use phrases like 'create a prd', 'write prd for', 'plan this feature', 'requirements for', or 'spec out'.

faq.question: Does this skill write code?
faq.answer: No, this skill only generates Product Requirements Documents. Other skills or the ralph-tui tool handle implementation.

faq.question: How many questions will I be asked?
faq.answer: Typically 2-4 rounds of questions. Each round covers a different aspect like goals, scope, users, and quality gates.

faq.question: What are quality gates?
faq.answer: Commands that must pass for every user story, such as type checking, linting, or tests. They ensure code quality across the implementation.

faq.question: How small should user stories be?
faq.answer: Each story should be completable in one focused AI agent session, typically 2-4 hours of work. Large features become multiple stories.

faq.question: What happens after the PRD is generated?
faq.answer: The PRD is wrapped in [PRD] markers for ralph-tui. Conversion tools can transform it into beads issues or a prd.json file for execution.
